 Why?

 A little of them all, I’m afraid.
 To explore: I sometimes feel like something is missing in my belief (I have a 14 yr old stepson that is severely mentally ill). For years I waited for him to give me an idea of what he wanted – in general. How he felt. (His brain doesn’t register pain. A sever burn leaves him astonished more than hurt.) He has no awareness of time or space. I had to come to grips with that, personally and spiritually in order to accept him as he is. I wondered why some people are so severely damaged while others, like myself, or normal. I soon come to realize that I had to go through that wonderment in order to reach another level of my faith. I needed help more than he did, sort of.
 To lead: If a person feels strongly about his/her belief, then they tend to be more confident. That’s both good and bad. Good in that if what they believe is wholesome and of a good nature, the followers can’t err in their support. On the other hand you have a Jim Jones’ doomsday cult, a.k.a. apostolic socialism, scenario.
 Of course a strong, confident leader mesmerizes his/her congregation despite the sermon in some cases.
 To belong: Some followers feel that their life is worthless without a leader of some sort. Even if they are taught that a certain religion requires no human (physical) leader, they are still drawn by one or more dominant figures. Most of these people have acquired this need during adolescence, some after a tragedy or something not considered as severe, such as divorce or separation.
 To share: When a person experiences certain incidents or spiritual relationships, they tend to want to share the experience. It is beyond the realm of normal (or what is considered normal to them), making it nothing less than supernatural or, in some instances, a miracle. During this period, and depending on the religion’s message, a basic truth has been attained that could have never been accomplished in any other way, but through a deliverer or savior. Soon the writing and teaching fall into place, completing a puzzle. If they stay focused on that faith they will soon see problems solved and mysteries revealed, even if it goes against all laws of man and nature.
 
 That is the way I see it.
 
 Hope this helps.

There are two possible interpretations of this question: 1) Why should I care what you think of me? or 2) Why should I care if what you think is the same as what I think? I can safely say to the first possibility that I don't really care if somebody doesn't like me for what I think. The second possibility raises the following questions: Should we offer unsolicited opinions? Is it right to judge others as bad for holding different opinions? I wouldn't advise offering unsolicited opinions out of the blue but I wouldn't stay silent if I disagreed with a stated opinion or if I were asked what my opinion was. As for judging others based on their opinions, I think we all know the answer to that.
